app

Class Ship

  • java.lang.Object
    • app.Ship
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Battleship, Cruiser, Destroyer, EmptySea, Submarine

    public class Ship
extends java.lang.Object

    This class represents a ship in the game Battleship. It is a part of the Battleship game application, which is run by the class BattleshipGame.

    This class regularly interacts with class Ocean.

    The subclasses of this class are: EmptySea, Battleship, Cruiser, Destroyer and Submarine.

    Since:
    17th December 2014
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Liran Harary (lharar01, 12837230)

      • setBowRow

        public boolean setBowRow(int bowRow)

        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • okToPlaceShipAt

        public boolean okToPlaceShipAt(int row,
                               int column,
                               boolean horizontal,
                               Ocean ocean)

        Returns whether or not it is okay to place this Ship with the given orientation and with its bow in the given row and column of the given Ocean object - all received as arguments.

        Performs the following checks:

        • The proposed row and column do not make this Ship exceed the boundaries of the Ocean object.
        • There are no other Ships on or all around this Ship's proposed location.

        It should be noted that this method does not modify this Ship or the Ocean object. Rather it merely says whether or not it is legal to do so.

        Parameters:
        row - Proposed Ship bow row.
        column - Proposed Ship bow column
        horizontal - Proposed Ship orientation
        ocean - Ocean object to place this Ship in
        Returns:
        Whether or not it is legal to place this Ship in the Ocean object

      • placeShipAt

        public void placeShipAt(int row,
                        int column,
                        boolean horizontal,
                        Ocean ocean)

        Places this Ship in the Ocean object received as an argument.

        This involves the following actions:

        • Setting bowRow to row's value.
        • Setting bowColumn to column's value.
        • Setting horizontal to horizontal's value.
        • Using Ocean's setShipInLocation method to place this Ship in the Ocean.

        It should be noted that a precondition to using this method is invoking the method okToPlaceShipAt with the same parameters. This is to ensure that it is legal to place this Ship in the given Ocean.

        Parameters:
        row - Requested bow row for this Ship.
        column - Requested bow column for this Ship.
        horizontal - Requested orientation for this Ship.
        ocean - Ocean to place this Ship in.

      • shootAt

        public boolean shootAt(int row,
                       int column)

        shoots at this Ship.

        If this Ship is not sunk and the shot row and column are part of it, this method:

        • Marks the corresponding part of this Ship's hit array as true.
        • Returns true.

        Otherwise, it returns false.

        Parameters:
        row - shot row.
        column - shot column.
        Returns:
        true if the shot hit a part of this Ship AND this Ship is not sunk.

      • isSunk

        public boolean isSunk()
        Returns whether or not this Ship has been sunk.
        Returns:
        true if this Ship has been sunk and false otherwise.

      • isPlaceHit

        public boolean isPlaceHit(int row,
                          int column)
        Returns whether or not the given place (row and column received as parameters) is part of this Ship and has been hit.
        Parameters:
        row - row to check if hit.
        column - column to check if hit.
        Returns:
        true if place is hit; false otherwise.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()

        Returns "S" to denote a (non-EmptySea) Ship.

        This symbol is then used in the Ocean's print method to determine if it is a real Ship, and if so determine its state by invoking various methods.

        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        "S"
